#Text=PREFACE
#Text=“ PAUL PRESCOTT'S CHARGE ” is presented to the public as the second volume of the Campaign Series .

#Text=Though wholly unlike the first volume , it is written in furtherance of the same main idea , that every boy 's life is a campaign , more or less difficult , in which success depends upon integrity and a steadfast adherence to duty .

#Text=How Paul Prescott gained strength by battling with adverse circumstances , and , under all discouragements , kept steadily before him the charge which he received from his dying father , is fully told ; and the author will be glad if the record shall prove an incentive and an encouragement to those boys who may have a similar campaign before them .
#Text=PAUL PRESCOTT'S CHARGE .
#Text=I.
#Text=SQUIRE NEWCOME .
#Text=“ HANNAH ! ”
#Text=The speaker was a tall , pompous-looking man , whose age appeared to verge close upon fifty .
#Text=He was sitting bolt upright in a high-backed chair , and looked as if it would be quite impossible to deviate from his position of unbending rigidity .

#Text=Squire Benjamin Newcome , as he was called , in the right of his position as Justice of the Peace , Chairman of the Selectmen , and wealthiest resident of Wrenville , was a man of rule and measure .
#Text=He was measured in his walk , measured in his utterance , and measured in all his transactions .
#Text=He might be called a dignified machine .
#Text=He had a very exalted conception of his own position , and the respect which he felt to be his due , not only from his own household , but from all who approached him .
#Text=If the President of the United States had called upon him , Squire Newcome would very probably have felt that he himself was the party who conferred distinction , and not received it .
#Text=Squire Newcome was a widower .
#Text=His wife , who was as different from himself as could well be conceived , did not live long after marriage .
#Text=She was chilled to death , as it was thought , by the dignified iceberg of whose establishment she had become a part .
#Text=She had left , however , a child , who had now grown to be a boy of twelve .
#Text=This boy was a thorn in the side of his father , who had endeavored in vain to mould him according to his idea of propriety .
#Text=But Ben was gifted with a spirit of fun , sometimes running into mischief , which was constantly bursting out in new directions , in spite of his father 's numerous and rather prosy lectures .
#Text=“ Han-nah ! ” again called Squire Newcome , separating the two syllables by a pause of deliberation , and strongly accenting the last syllable , -- a habit of his with all proper names .
#Text=Hannah was the Irish servant of all work , who was just then engaged in mixing up bread in the room adjoining , which was the kitchen .
#Text=Feeling a natural reluctance to appear before her employer with her hands covered with dough , she hastily washed them .
#Text=All this , however , took time , and before she responded to the first summons , the second “ Han-nah ! ” delivered with a little sharp emphasis , had been uttered .
#Text=At length she appeared at the door of the sitting-room .
#Text=“ Han-nah ! ” said Squire Newcome , fixing his cold gray eye upon her , “ when you hear my voice a calling you , it is your duty to answer the summons IMMEJIATELY . ”
#Text=I have endeavored to represent the Squire 's pronunciation of the last word .
#Text=“ So I would have come IMMEJOUSLY , ” said Hannah , displaying a most reprehensible ignorance , “ but me hands were all covered with flour . ”
#Text=“ That makes no difference , ” interrupted the Squire .
#Text=“ Flour is an accidental circumstance . ”
#Text=“ What 's that ? ” thought Hannah , opening her eyes in amazement .
#Text=“ And should not be allowed to interpose an obstacle to an IMMEJIATE answer to my summons . ”
#Text=“ Sir , ” said Hannah , who guessed at the meaning though she did not understand the words , “ you would n't have me dirty the door-handle with me doughy hands ? ”
#Text=“ That could easily be remedied by ablution . ”
#Text=“ There ai n't any ablution in the house , ” said the mystified Hannah .
#Text=“ I mean , ” Squire Newcome condescended to explain , “ the application of water -- in short , washing . ”
#Text=“ Shure , ” said Hannah , as light broke in upon her mind , “ I never knew that was what they called it before . ”
#Text=“ Is Ben-ja-min at home ? ”
#Text=“ Yes , sir .
#Text=He was out playin ' in the yard a minute ago .
#Text=I guess you can see him from the winder . ”

#Text=So saying she stepped forward , and looking out , all at once gave a shrill scream , and rushed from the room , leaving her employer in his bolt-upright attitude gazing after her with as much astonishment as he was capable of .
#Text=The cause of her sudden exit was revealed on looking out of the window .
#Text=Master Benjamin , or Ben , as he was called everywhere except in his own family , had got possession of the black kitten , and appeared to be submerging her in the hogshead of rainwater .

#Text=“ O , you wicked , cruel boy , to drown poor Kitty ! ” exclaimed the indignant Hannah , rushing into the yard and endeavoring to snatch her feline favorite -- an attempt which Ben stoutly resisted .
#Text=Doubtless the poor kitten would have fared badly between the two , had not the window opened , and the deliberate voice of his father , called out in tones which Ben saw fit to heed .
#Text=“ What ? ”
#Text=“ Come into my presence immejiately , and learn to answer me with more respect . ”
#Text=Ben came in looking half defiant .
#Text=His father , whose perpendicularity made him look like a sitting grenadier , commenced the examination thus : --
#Text=“ I wish you to inform me what you was a doing of when I spoke to you . ”
